Subjective: Profound fatigue for ~2 months; wakes up tired despite sleeping a lot. Associated with increased muscle pain, back pain, and morning stiffness. Sleep described as possibly more superficial. Impact: Continues working but feels exhausted by end of day; rests on weekends. Physical activity maintained (climbing 2-3x/week, cycling). No clear trigger. Meds: Hay fever pills/drops, effective. Negatives: No preceding illness, no major life stressors, no decline in physical conditioning. No shortness of breath, chest pain, or palpitations. No snoring. Appetite normal, weight stable (72kg). Bowel/urinary habits unchanged. No specific joint pain. Social: Physically active. FH: Father with back problems. ICE: Concern about an underlying physical problem; wonders about rheumatism based on online search.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/60, HR 40-60 bpm. General: Appears well. Lungs: Clear to auscultation. Heart: Normal heart sounds. Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, supple, lively peristalsis. Musculoskeletal: Pain on palpation paravertebrally in lower back. No pain on pelvic compression. Neck and shoulder range of motion full and painless.
Assessment: Fatigue, unspecified. Myalgia. Differential diagnosis includes anemia, thyroid dysfunction, and inflammatory/rheumatological conditions. Cardiopulmonary cause less likely.
Plan: 1. Labs: Blood tests to check for anemia, thyroid function, and inflammation markers. 2. Explanation: Discussed need to rule out common causes of fatigue. Reassured that normal inflammation markers make rheumatoid arthritis unlikely. 3. Follow-up: Patient to get blood drawn. Call clinic for results and to schedule a phone appointment in 2 days.
